revised_title: Investigations on Hem-agglutinin and Hemolysin Presence in Infectious and Non-Infectious Diseases Blood
tldr: The authors conducted a series of experiments to study the presence of hem-agglutinins and hemolysins in the blood of individuals with infectious and non-infectious diseases. They found that serum from healthy individuals could agglutinate red blood cells from other healthy individuals, but not their own. The authors also discovered that heating serum at 60°C could enhance the agglutinative action, and that red blood cells exposed to high temperatures could still exert specific agglutinative actions. However, they found that sand heated to similar temperatures was inert.
